hints_html:
First, we find the equation of the tangent line. Remember that the derivative at a point gives you the slope of the tangent line.

Once you have the tangent line, use it to approximate \(f(x)\). Thus, we have

\(\displaystyle f(x) \approx y = f'(3)x + b\)

where we find \(b\) by plugging in the point \(\displaystyle (3,2)\) into \(\displaystyle y=f'(3)x+b\). Then set the above equation to 0 and solve for \(x\).

To see this, notice that the equation of the line using the point slope formula is given by

\(\displaystyle \frac{y-2}{x-3} = f'(3) = 5\).

Isolating gives

\(\displaystyle y-2 = 5(x-3)\)

and simplifying one last time

\(\displaystyle y = 5x -13\).

We are using this line to approximate \(\displaystyle f(x)\). Thus, if we set \(\displaystyle y=0\) and solve, we can get an approximation to the root of \(\displaystyle f(x)\). Hence, set \(\displaystyle 0 = 5x- 13\) which gives \(\displaystyle x = 13/5 = 2.6\). Thus the correct answer is (C).

statement_html:
Let \(f\) be a differentiable function such that \(\displaystyle f(3)=2\) and \(\displaystyle f'(3)=5.\) If the tangent line to the graph of \(f\) at \(a=3\) is used to approximate \(f(x)\), then the approximate solution for \(x\) to the equation \(f(x)=0\) is

(A) \(x=0.4\).

(B) \(x=0.5\).

(C) \(x=2.6\).

(D) \(x=3.4\).

(E) \(x=5.5\).
